autumn.lang

Interface Tuple<T extends Tuple>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Tuple>, java.lang.Iterable, java.io.Serializable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractTuple

    public interface Tuple<T extends Tuple>
extends java.lang.Iterable, java.lang.Comparable<Tuple>, java.io.Serializable
    An instance of this interface is a tuple.

    Unlike some languages, tuples in Autumn are so-called "named tuples". In other words, tuples also map keys to values, rather than being simply linear.

    An implementation of this interface should provide a single public constructor. The constructor should have one formal-parameter for each element. As a result, a user should be able to create an instance by simply calling that constructor.

    Example tuple(String, Integer, String):
    Tuple greeting = new Tuple("Hello", 2, "World");

    An implementation of this interface should also provide a static method instance(). This method should return an instance of the implementation, when invoked. Thus, the return type of the method would be the type of the enclosing implementation. The returned instance must be immutable. Each element in the returned instance should be set to the default value for its type. Remember, the size of a tuple is a constant. Even though the elements are set to their defaults, the size() is still the element count.

    Warning:

    Tuples should not be used to create recursive data, because this could cause unbounded recursion in the equals(Object), hashCode(), or toString() method.

        This method creates a list containing the key part of each element.

        Element [i] of the returned list is the key of the element [i] in this tuple.

        Returns:
        the aforedescribed immutable list.

      • clear

        Tuple<T> clear()
        This method sets the value of each element to its default value.

        This method does not affect the size of the tuple.

        Returns:
        this object, if this tuple is mutable; otherwise, return a modified copy thereof.

      • set

        Tuple<T> set(int index,
           java.lang.Object value)
        This method assigns a new value to the element at a given index.

        Auto-unboxing will be performed, if necessary. However, the unboxed value will not be auto-widened.

        Parameters:
        index - is the index of the element to assign.
        value - is the new value.
        Returns:
        this tuple, if this tuple is mutable; otherwise, returned a modified copy thereof.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index does not refer to an actual element.
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if the object is not of an acceptable type.

      • assign

        Tuple<T> assign(Tuple<?> other)
        This method makes the elements in this tuple be those of another tuple.

        In short, this method copies each of the elements of the other tuple into this tuple. Each element is cast to the appropriate type in order to ensure type-safety.

        Parameters:
        other - is the tuple that will supply the new elements for this tuple.
        Returns:
        this tuple, if this tuple is mutable; otherwise, returned a modified copy thereof.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if other is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the other.size() != this.size().
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this tuple is not mutable.
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if any of the elements cannot be assigned due to its type.

      • isMutable

        boolean isMutable()
        This method determines whether this tuple is mutable.
        Returns:
        ! isReadonly().

        boolean isImmutable()
        This method determines whether this tuple is immutable.
        Returns:
        ! isMutable().

      • copy

        Tuple<T> copy()
        This method creates a shallow copy of this tuple.

        If this tuple is mutable, then the copy will be mutable. If this tuple is immutable, then the copy will be immutable.

        Returns:
        a copy of this tuple.

      • iterator

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Object> iterator()
        This method creates an iterator over this tuple.

        The iterator does not support the optional remove() operation.

        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable
        Returns:

      • listIterator

        java.util.ListIterator<java.lang.Object> listIterator()
        This method creates a list-iterator over this tuple.

        The iterator does not support the optional add and remove operations.

        The iterator supports the set(Object) operation, iff this tuple is mutable.

        Returns:
        the aforedescribed iterator.

      • compareTo

        int compareTo(Tuple other)
        This method compares this tuple to another given tuple.

        Tuples are compared based on the following information. Firstly, tuples are compared based on their length. Shorter tuples are less-than longer tuples. Secondly, tuples are compared based on their keys. Since each key is a string, it can be compared to the equally index key in other. This enforces a sort of lexicographic order. Thirdly, the tuples are compared based on their comparable values at equal indexes. If none of the values are comparable, then an IllegalStateException is thrown. The exception should include an informative error message.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Tuple>
        Parameters:
        other - is the other tuple itself.
        Returns:
        an integer indicating the relationship of this tuple to the other tuple.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this method is not supported by this instance.

      • equals

        boolean equals(java.lang.Object other)
        This method determines whether this tuple equals another given tuple.

        Equality Rules:

        1. If this is the same object as other, then return true.
        2. If other is not a Tuple, return false.
        3. If this.size() != other.size(), return false.
        4. Return this.keys().equals(other.keys()) && this.values().equals(other.values()).

        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        other - is the other tuple itself.
        Returns:
        true, iff this tuple equals the other tuple.

      • hashCode

        int hashCode()
        This method computes a hash-code for this tuple.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        this.toMap().hashCode()

      • toString

        java.lang.String toString()
        This method creates a string representation of this tuple.

        The string representation of a tuple is a parentheses enclosed list of the values therein.
        Examples: () (1, 2) ("Hello", "Alien", "World")

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        the string representation of this tuple.
